JournalInfo.JournalSubTitle: Zeitschrift für Rohstoffe, Geotechnik, Metallurgie, Werkstoffe, Maschinen- und Anlagentechnik

ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Overview of 50 Years of Development in Electroslag Remelting in Austria
Ein Überblick über 50 Jahre ESU-Entwicklung in Österreich

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The paper deals with the development work in the field of Electroslag Remelting (ESR), which has been executed in Austria since 1964 by Gebr. Böhler & Co. AG and since 1973 by INTECO Internationale Technische Beratung GmbH.

Electroslag Remelting has initially been executed in open air independent from plant concept i.e. static crucible–single electrode or collar mould–electrode change. Difficulties in controlling oxygen and hydrogen in larger size ingots finally led to protective gas remelting from 1996 on.

Specific plant concepts were developed for the production of high nitrogen steels—Pressure-ESR (PESR) and for the continuous production of small size billets at economic meltrates—Electroslag Rapid Remelting (ESRR®).
Due to the need for larger and larger forgings, ESR ingot sizes and weights have been increased up to 2600 mm ingot diameter and 260 t in weight.

Abstract.Heading: Zusammenfassung
Abstract.Para: Der vorliegende Bericht befasst sich mit der Entwicklung der Anlagen- und Verfahrenstechnologie zum Elektroschlacke-Umschmelzen (ESU) in Österreich durch die Firma Gebr. Böhler & Co. AG seit 1964 und die Firma INTECO Internationale Technische Beratung GmbH seit 1973.

Ursprünglich wurde das Elektroschlacke-Umschmelz-Verfahren an Luft durchgeführt, unabhängig vom Anlagenkonzept wie Standtiegel mit einer einzelnen Abschmelzelektrode oder kurze Kokille mit Blockabzug und Elektrodenwechsel. Schwierigkeiten zur Erzielung einer ausreichenden Kontrolle von Wasserstoff und Sauerstoff, insbesondere bei der Erzeugung größerer Umschmelzblöcke haben schließlich ab 1996 zum Umschmelzen unter Schutzgas geführt.

Spezielle Anlagenkonzepte wurden für die Herstellung hochstickstoffliegierter Stähle entwickelt – das Druck-ESU-Verfahren (DESU) und für eine kontinuierliche Herstellung kleiner Umschmelzquerschnitte mit höheren Schmelzraten – das Elektroschlacke-Schnellschmelzen (ESRR®).

Aufgrund des steigenden Bedarfs an immer größeren Schmiedestücken werden größere ESU-Blöcke benötigt. Dies hat zu Anlagen für die Herstellung von ESU-Blöcken mit 2600 mm Blockdurchmesser und 260 t Gewicht geführt.

ArticleNote.SimplePara: The author was affiliated with Gebr. Böhler & Co. AG in Kapfenberg between 1960 and 1973 and has founded INTECO Internationale Technische Beratung GmbH in 1973.

Body.Para: In the present paper, an attempt is made to remember and describe the introduction of the Electroslag Remelting (ESR) process in Austria as well as major developments of the process since then, up to its present status as presented by the recent plant installations based on the latest technology.

Before dealing with development work done in Austria, it is appropriate to mention earlier work. Undoubtedly the first person who remelted a consumable electrode under a blanket of slag was Hopkins, based on preliminary work by M. W. Kellog, then known as the Kellog Electric Ingot process. [1–4] In the 1950ies the process was applied by Firth Sterling Inc. [5], who even then already used electrode change. Due to the restrictive licensing policy of Firth Sterling Inc., the ESR process was not pursued any further once the VAR process had become popular for consumable electrode remelting in the US.

Independent development work at the Paton Welding Institute in Kiev, based on the Electroslag welding process by B. I. Medovar, resulted in an industrial application of the ESR process in the Dnjeprospezstal works in Zaparoshje/Ukraine in the former Soviet Union [6–8].
In the 1960ies based on reports from the US and Kiev, development work started in Great Britain [9], France [10], and Austria [11].

From 1964 onwards, extensive research was conducted at Gebr. Böhler & Co AG in Kapfenberg/Austria with the aim to understand and clarify the technological and metallurgical phenomena of the ESR process. For this purpose a manually controlled pilot plant with a transformer rating of 350 KVA and an output on the secondary side of 60 V/5 kA was available (Fig. 1) in which ingots of up to 300 mm in diameter and 700 mm in length could be produced. The results obtained by this work were described in the author’s thesis [12, 13] at the Mining and Metallurgical University in Leoben, Austria, in 1967.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Pilot Plant at the Böhler Works in Kapfenberg in 1964

Body.Para: Based on these results and the knowledge gained, a first production scale plant for the production of ingots with initially 800 mm diameter and 4 m length was built in 1967 utilizing a moveable short collar mould and exchange of consumable electrodes. This design offered a high degree of freedom with regard to ingot length and diameter independent from mould length, electrode length and electrode—mould diameter ratio. The max. mould diameter of this plant was soon increased to 1000 mm so that, already in 1968, ingots with a weight of up to 24 metric tons could be produced (Fig. 2).

CaptionContent.SimplePara: First ESR Production Plant at the Böhler Works in Kapfenberg in 1967

Body.Para: In these early days of commercial ESR production, the capability of the process for efficient desulphurization was of prime importance (Fig. 3), although control of oxygen contents and improved micro structure were appreciated as well, which altogether led to improved toughness values particularly in the transverse direction.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Iso-Desulphurization Lines in ESR in the Quaternary Slag System CaO-Al2O3-CaF2-SiO2 [12, 13]

Body.Para: After the successful start up of the first production scale plant, Böhler decided to market ESR plants and the related technology to other specialty steel producers. The first customers were Uddeholm (1968) and Bofors (1970) in Sweden. The flexibility of Böhler’s plant and process design features (Fig. 4) applying moveable collar moulds and electrode change proved to be competitive and made it well accepted in the market. This forced certain competitors to copy the concept either directly or indirectly with certain modifications, such as retractable base plates instead of moveable moulds.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Scheme of the Böhler ESR-Plant Configuration [14]

Body.Para: Between 1967 and 1972, Böhler applied for well over 30 patents which dealt with ESR process technology or plant design features. At the same time, 16 production scale ESR plants, including Böhler’s own plants, were built and subsequently put into operation by Böhler and its licensees (Heurtey in Paris and Dravo Corp. in Pittsburgh).

Additional furnaces, mostly static mould-single electrode plants, were installed by Böhler’s competitors Consarc Inc. in the US and Leybold Heräus, today ALD in Germany. Those two are still in the market, while Böhler withdrew around 1990.

One major disadvantage of Böhler’s otherwise very successful plant concept was the use of flexible high current cables between the power supply and the electrode carriages, as shown in Fig. 4 [14], which resulted in a wide open high current loop and consequently in a high furnace impedance and high inductive losses at net frequency. With typical inductance values XL between 4.0 and 5.0 mOhm, remelt currents of more than 25 kA without additional measures were difficult to achieve when using standard transformers. This led to the introduction of thyristor controlled low frequency power supplies from 1970 onwards, which did, however, bring with it increased capital investment costs.

The initial success of the ESR process between 1967 and 1972 did not continue at the same pace but slowed down quite remarkably in the following 10 to 15 years. The reason for the initial success of the ESR process was the fact that in those days it was more or less the only commercial process by which lowest sulphur levels and best cleanliness in regard to non-metallic inclusions could efficiently be achieved.

From 1970 onwards, ladle furnaces of ASEA—SKF and Finkl—Moore and CaSi injection plants (CAB) came increasingly into use and represented processes less costly than ESR and equally effective in controlling sulphur and inclusion levels in steels. This slowed down a further expansion of the ESR process quite drastically. This dramatic impact of secondary metallurgy becomes evident if one considers that, in only 5 years between 1968 and 1973, 16 Böhler ESR furnaces, not counting the ones by competitors, were sold in comparison to only 9 furnaces in 16 years between 1974 and 1990 when Böhler decided to withdraw from the market. Only slowly the industry discovered that ESR was offering additional benefits besides desulphurization, such as improved homogeneity as well as micro and macro structure of the remelted steels and alloys.

In 1973 also INTECO, Internationale Technische Beratung Ges.m.b.H., founded by the author and his colleague Ludwig Schwarz, entered into the then difficult market for ESR equipment with a new plant concept featuring short collar moulds, retractable base plates, and electrode change, combined with an improved high current loop, which eliminated the flexible cables and used vertical high current tubes, arranged in parallel to the consumable electrode and ingot respectively with sliding contacts to conduct the power to electrode and base plate, respectively (Fig. 5). With this new design, reduced inductance values of XL between 1.8 at the start and 2.5 mOhm at an ingot length of 5 to 6 m were achieved. Thereby it became possible to operate at net frequency of up to 40 kA still maintaining an acceptable power factor between 0.67 and 0.71. The first plants of this new concept were put in operation at Zelezarna Ravne in Slovenia (then Yugoslavia) in 1980 and at Thyssen Edelstahlwerke in Krefeld in1985 (Figs. 6 and 7).

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Scheme of the INTECO ESR-Plant Configuration
ESR-Plant at Zelezarna Ravne (1983) for Ingots of 1 m dia. by 6 m in Length

Body.Para: Electroslag Remelting as initially introduced was carried out in open air. The access of oxygen seemed desirable to oxidize the sulphur from the slag, thereby keeping the sulphur levels of the slag bath low and maintaining the desulphurizing capacity of the slag even with longer ingots [12, 13]. On the other hand, hydrogen pick up (Fig. 8), particularly during the summer months, was an issue when producing larger diameter ingots of sensitive forging grades [15, 16]. To overcome this problem, mould covers were introduced in combination with injection of inert gas or dry air into the gap between slag surface, electrode, and mould walls and cover. Yet despite these measures, it was hardly possible to achieve hydrogen contents below 2.0–2.5 ppm in ESR ingots even if well degassed consumable electrodes were remelted.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: The Behaviour of Hydrogen in Electroslag Remelting in Dependence on the Hydrogen Content of the Electrode and the Atmosphere above the Slag Pool [16]

Body.Para: The control of oxygen in ESR, as already shown in early works [12, 17] on this topic, is governed by the activities of the main deoxidizing elements Si and Al and the activities of the respective oxides SiO2 and Al2O3 in the slag (Fig. 9). Under these conditions Si could become a very strong deoxidizer with low SiO2 concentrations, i.e. low (SiO2) values of the slag so that Si becomes then capable to even reduce Al2O3 from the slag thereby increasing the Al contents of the remelted steel.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Influence of Slag Basicity (CaO + MgO)SiO2 on the Average Oxygen Contents of Various Steel Grades After Electroslag Remelting [12, 13]

Body.Para: Already in the early days, it was known that the oxygen contents in the remelted steels also depended on the partial pressure of oxygen over the slag pool (Fig. 10), partly due to direct transfer not only with the aid of ions in the slag which had changing valencies, such as Fe2 + and Fe3 +, but also by the ions of Mn and Cr even at low concentrations in the slag. On the other hand, oxygen is also introduced into the slag due to an oxidation of the electrode surface resulting in scale formation ([11, 16]; Fig. 11).

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Influence of the Partial Pressure of Oxygen in the Gas Phase on the Oxygen Contents of the Alloy AISI 304 (X5CrNi18-9) after Electroslag Remelting [12, 13]
Schematic of Oxidizing and Reducing Reactions when Electroslag Remelting is Carried Out on Air [16]

Body.Para: Even low Fe2 + and Fe3 + concentrations in the slag lead to an oxidation of the Si of the metal and in turn to an increase of the SiO2 concentrations of the slag, thereby reducing the overall deoxidation efficiency of the slag. In long ingots without the application of countermeasures, the SiO2 concentrations of the slag could reach an unacceptable amount of 15 to 20 % at the top portion of the ingot.
To counteract this problem, slag deoxidation with Al and CaAl was applied, which helped to keep the slag SiO2 below 8 to 10 % at the risk of Al pick up in the remelted metal.

During the late 1970ies, martensitic Cr steels for turbine rotor applications with specifications of Si below 0.10 % and Al below 0.010 % were introduced. These steels were produced by vacuum carbon deoxidation and were initially cast as conventional ingots. Increasingly stringent quality requirements with regard to ingot structure and homogeneity were calling for remelted ingots of adequate size and weight. ESR on air of such grades became a tricky procedure as also stringent cleanliness requirements had to be met.

Sulphur after the introduction of ladle furnaces and CaSi injection plants was no longer an issue in ESR. Although ESR plant operators were continuously struggling to control hydrogen and oxygen contents and to avoid or at least reduce losses of oxidisable elements, the drive for the development of protective gas ESR plants which are the standard today was limited.

It was no earlier than 1997 when the first INTECO protective gas ESR plant based on the Austrian patent AT 406.457 [18] was started up at the Accaierie Valbruna plant in Vicenza. The concept of this plant (Fig. 12) included a retractable base plate and electrode change and ensured a 100 % protective gas operation with the consumable electrode during remelting being kept under an airtight protective gas hood. This can be considered as a milestone in ESR operation and as the true starting point of protective gas ESR as from then onwards all ESR plants installed, whether electrode change, collar mould or static crucible, single electrode, and more recently also static crucible, electrode change, have incorporated an airtight protective gas hood and atmospheric control.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Protective Gas ESR-Plant, Acciaierie Valbruna S.p.A., Italy, also Capable of ESRR®

Body.Para: Subsequent plants according to this concept were built by INTECO for Edelstahl Breitenfeld in Austria as well as Kind & Co. and Krupp Südwestfalen in Germany. It was only natural that, following this trend, also static mould-single electrode plants were equipped with protective gas hoods, such as the two 1300 mm dia. 30 t units which INTECO supplied to DEW in Krefeld in 2005. Utilizing protective gas hoods for all plant configurations led to coaxial high current power loops of various designs thereby further reducing furnace impedances to XL values in the range of 1.0 and 1.5 mOhm.

Although the general introduction of protective gas ESR technology was not done until 1997, “protective gas operations” have been applied already since 1970 in pressurized ESR plants used for the production of alloys containing nitrogen contents above the solubility at atmospheric pressure.

The Pressure ESR process (PESR) was first introduced by Böhler in Kapfenberg for the production of high nitrogen alloys. Based on lab scale experiments, a pilot plant was installed in Kapfenberg in 1970 [19], which was capable of producing ingots with 400 mm diameter and 1 t in weight under a max. pressure of 25 bar (Fig. 13). A first production scale PESR plant capable of producing ingots of 1000 mm diameter and 14 t in weight under a maximum gas pressure of 42 bar was installed by INTECO at the former Krupp Metall- und Schmiedewerke GmbH in Essen in 1980 ([20, 21]; Figs. 14 and 15).

CaptionContent.SimplePara: 1 t PESR Pilot Plant at Böhler in Kapfenberg in 1971 for Operating Pressure of max. 25 bar
Scheme of Pressurized ESR-Plant at Krupp Metall- und Schmiedewerke [21]
14 t PESR Production Plant at Krupp Metall- und Schmiedewerke for Operating Pressure of max. 42 bar (1980)

Body.Para: The reason for the high pressure of this first production scale plant was the aim to achieve remarkably higher yield points with an alloy primarily used for generator end bell rings in the late 1960ies. This alloy W.Nr. 1.3812 or X 40 MnCr 18 5 could hold in solution only 0.15 % N at atmospheric pressure. To achieve the desired high yield strength of more than 1500 N/mm2 in the cold worked condition, a nitrogen content of 0.70 % would have been required, which consequently, including necessary reserves, called for a pressure of 42 bar.

In the 1980ies, however, this alloy was abandoned. The modern alloy for generator end bell rings W.Nr. 1.3816 or P 900, as then introduced by Krupp Metall und Schmiedewerke, today Energietechnik Essen GmbH, contains 18 % Mn and 18 % Cr and can dissolve up to 0.60 % nitrogen already at atmospheric pressure [22, 32]. To obtain a content of 1.0 % in order to reach the desired yield points, a pressure of max. 5 bar during remelting is sufficient.

Since 1980 approximately half a dozen PESR plants have been installed by INTECO and ALD in Europe and the USA and most recently, under installation, also in China. Apart from the plant in Essen, renewed by ALD in 1987, all other plants were designed for operating pressures of max. 16 bar.

Industrial ESR plants until 1990/1995 were mainly producing ingots in the range between 500 and 1500 mm in diameter. For smaller ingots ESR was not economic due to the low production rates and the difficulties and costs in producing the consumable electrodes with even smaller cross sections, unless continuously cast billets were available. Nevertheless a certain interest for small size ingots in ESR quality existed, particularly for high speed and other tool steels but also for high alloyed stainless steels and Ni-base alloys.

A reasonable solution for such cases was presented by INTECO with the development of the so called Electroslag Rapid Remelting Process (ESRR®), covered by the Austrian patent AT 406.384 B, dtd. 09.04.1996 [23, 24], the main features of which are characterized by remelting of a consumable electrode of a cross section larger than the cross section of the remelted ingot or billet in a T-shaped mould. The upper and wider part of the T-shaped mould is equipped with a graphite ring in the slag zone for transfer of the major portion of the melting current, all of which is first conducted into the slag pool by the consumable electrode, back to the power supply. Only a minor portion of the melting current goes through the remelted billet and current conducting withdrawal rollers back to the power supply. In the wide upper part of the T-shaped mould, electrodes of comparably large cross sections are remelted at melt rates up to 3 to 4 times of the standard ESR melt rates (Figs. 16, 17). The liquid metal is collected in the narrower part of the mould where the metal solidifies and wherefrom the ESRR billet is withdrawn continuously. A constant liquid metal level is maintained by a radioactive level detector which gives its signal to the withdrawal roller system arranged just below the mould. Cutting of the strands at a desired length can be carried out below the guide rolls so that, in combination with electrode change, a fully continuous operation becomes possible [25].

CaptionContent.SimplePara: Trial Remelting of a 270 mm dia. Electrode into a 160 mm dia. Billet at the ESR Plant at Lippendorf, Germany in 1996
Scheme of the Continuous ESRR-Plant at Acciaierie Valbruna S.p.A., Vicenza in 2005 [25]

Body.Para: The very first production scale operation was performed in the protective gas ESR plant at Accaierie Valbruna in Vicenza in 1997 where single billets of approximately 4 m length were produced. A second ESRR plant installed at Accaierie Valbruna in 2005 included a billet cutting device so that continuous operation was made possible ([25]; Fig. 17). The production rate, when producing stainless steel billets of AISI 304 or similar grades in as cast sections of 145 and 200 mm square, was in the order of 500 to 600 kg/h which is 3 or 4 times more than the standard ESR melt rates. Further ESRR® installations were supplied by INTECO to Ugitech in France [26], Changwon in Korea and Xingtai in China [27] between 2004 and 2010.

Until 2005 the maximum ingot sizes in ESR plants were up to 1600 mm in diameter and 75 t in weight. One exception was an ESR plant supplied by Leybold Heräus to Saarschmiede in Völklingen, put into operation in the early 1970ies, in which ingots of 2300 mm dia. and 160 t in weight could be produced by simultaneously remelting four consumable electrodes each of which being connected to a low frequency power supply in a collar mould and ingot withdrawal by a retractable base plate.

It was between 1995 and 2005 that a number of forging shops invested in new installations of heavy presses with capacities of up to and in excess of 15 MN and modern control systems, replacing older equipment with max. capacities between 6 and 10 MN, which had come into the years. The start up of these new forging facilities created a requirement for larger size ingots in particular also in ESR quality. From 2008 onwards, this gave rise to the installation of a number of ESR plants capable of producing ingots between 100 and 260 t in weight ([28, 29]; Figs. 18, 19). Different plant concepts were applied to these plants, such as collar mould with retractable base plate and electrode change but also static crucible plants, most of them with electrode change. All of these new plants are applying protective gas remelting in order to safely control hydrogen and oxygen levels in the remelted ingots.

CaptionContent.SimplePara: 2600 mm dia. × 247 t ESR Ingot Produced at Forgiatura A. Vienna S.p.A. in October 2011
ESR-Plant for 260 t Ingots at Forgiatura A. Vienna S.p.A., Italy

Body.Para: Five such plants with up to 260 t ingot weight and ingot diameters ranging from 1700 mm up to 2600 mm have been supplied from Austria by INTECO in Italy (Figs. 18, 19), Germany, and Japan [28]. Three other plants with ingots weighing between 80 t and 145 t have been supplied by Consarc [30] and ALD [31], respectively.

Summarizing, the impact of work executed in or from Austria on the present status of the ESR process has been quite remarkable if one considers the 32 patents and patent applications of Böhler between 1967 and 1972 and 23 patents and patent applications of INTECO since 1974 in this field. The most memorable contributions were done in 1967 on the commercialisation of Böhler’s flexible ESR plant configuration with moveable mould and electrode change as well as INTECO’s worldwide first commercial pressure ESR plant for 1000 mm diameter—14 t ingots built for operation under 42 bar nitrogen pressure.

Other remarkable innovations are the development of the ESRR®, Electroslag Rapid Remelting process, for a continuous production of small size ESR billets at competitive higher melt rates in 1996 as well as the introduction of protective gas ESR for plants with collar moulds and electrode change also in 1996. Since then protective gas remelting has become a standard for all new plant installations regardless of whether they are collar mould or static crucible, each with or without electrode change.

These ongoing developments and efforts were topped in 2011 with the installation of a plant for the production of 260 t ingots with 2600 mm diameter in a static crucible by remelting four 65 t electrodes and applying electrode change (Figs. 18, 19).

In total, between 1967 and 1990, 25 ESR plants were built by Böhler and six plants by INTECO. Since 1990, 54 plants have additionally been supplied, modernized, or are under construction by INTECO, with nine plants alone in 2015. Among the later installations since 1990, four plants are pressure ESR plants and five are ESRR® plants.
Today in Austria a number of ESR Plants including pressure ESR are in operation at the Böhler Specialty Steel Plant of voestalpine in Kapfenberg, and Edelstahl Breitenfeld GmbH.

FormalPara.Heading: Conflict of interest
FormalPara.Para: The authors declare that there are no actual or potential conflicts of interest in relation to this article.
